intro: Daucus rupestris, commonly known as the rock parsley, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes many aromatic herbs and vegetables. The plant is characterized by its slender stems, finely divided leaves, and small white or yellowish flowers arranged in umbels. It thrives in rocky or gravelly soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats. Daucus rupestris is not widely cultivated but is of interest to botanists and horticulturists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
